title: Grimmia
text:
Grimmia is a <a href="genus">genus</a> of <a href="moss">moss</a>es (Bryophyta), originally named by <a href="Jakob%20Friedrich%20Ehrhart">Jakob Friedrich Ehrhart</a> in honour of <a href="Johann%20Friedrich%20Carl%20Grimm">Johann Friedrich Carl Grimm</a>, a <a href="physician">physician</a> and <a href="botanist">botanist</a> from <a href="Gotha%20%28town%29">Gotha</a>, <a href="Germany">Germany</a>.
Geographic distribution.
Although predominantly occurring in the moderate zones, representatives of the <a href="Cosmopolitan%20distribution">cosmopolitan</a> <a href="genus">genus</a> "Grimmia" may be found in all parts of the world, from <a href="Alaska">Alaska</a> to the most southern point of <a href="Chile">Chile</a>, and from <a href="Siberia">Siberia</a> to <a href="South%20Africa">South Africa</a>, though in <a href="Tropics">tropic regions</a>, e.g. <a href="Hawaii">Hawaii</a> and <a href="Indonesia">Indonesia</a>, "Grimmia" species only occur high up in the mountains.
Identification.
"Grimmia" is a notoriously difficult genus in terms of <a href="Identification%20%28biology%29">identification</a>, and in the majority of <a href="Herbarium">herbaria</a> a considerable number of species was found misidentified. The <a href="United%20States">American</a> <a href="bryologist">bryologist</a> <a href="Geneva%20Sayre">Geneva Sayre</a> (1911–1992), who worked for many years on a <a href="monograph">monograph</a> of the North American "Grimmias", indicated in an original way these difficulties, as she said: "it contains an ambigua, a varia, a decipiens, a controversa, a revisa and at least two anomalas".
Publications.
In the "<a href="Index%20Muscorum">Index Muscorum</a>", the genus "Grimmia" is represented with 800 names of <a href="Biological%20classification">published</a> <a href="species">species</a>. As since <a href="Leopold%20Loeske">Loeske</a> (1930), no revision of the <a href="Europe">Europe</a>an species had been carried out.
The <a href="Dutch%20people">Dutch</a> bryologist H. C. Greven started in 1990 with "Grimmia" <a href="fieldwork">fieldwork</a> and a revision of the "Grimmia" collections from important European herbaria. The results were published in ""Grimmia" Hedw. (Grimmiaceae, Musci) in Europe".
After examining the "Grimmia" collections from herbaria in <a href="North%20America">North-</a> and <a href="South%20America">South America</a>, <a href="South%20Africa">South Africa</a>, <a href="Australia">Australia</a> and <a href="New%20Zealand">New Zealand</a>, and about 50 "Grimmia" collecting trips in all <a href="continents">continents</a>, "Grimmias of the World" was published. An important contribution was the revision of "Grimmia" in North America.
In the past decades, some more bryologists became interested in the genus "Grimmia". Jesús Muñoz published a herbaria revision of "Grimmia" in Latin America, and Maier studied herbarium <a href="Biological%20specimen">specimens</a> of "Grimmia" from the <a href="Himalaya">Himalaya</a>.
